TextEquiv.Unicode: polver and the quickening spirite. For
the Apostle himselfe shewing what he
meant by ye naturall & spirituall body,
addeth this immediatly & saith: There
is a naturalll bodye, and there is a spiri
tuall bodie : as it is written. The first
man Adam was made a living soule,
and the last Adam was made a dure
kening spirite. And yet agayne more
plainely he sayth: Howbeit that is not
first which is spirituall, but that which
is naturall, and then that which is spy
rituall. The first man is of the earth
earthly:the second man is the Lord from
heaven. As is the earthly, suth are they
that are earthly: fas is the heavenly,
suth are they also that are heavenlie,
And as we have born the image of the
earthly, so shal wee beare the image of
the heavenlie. So then Paul calleth
that naturall bodie and earthly body,
which wee have of our first father A
dam, whose quickening is of the soule
and by it doeth live. And hee calleth
the spiritual body, and heavenly body,
which wee have of Christ, and made
to the likenesse of the body of Christ,
which although it bee a very body in
deede, and the fleshe thereof bee very
flesh indeed, yet notwithstanding it is
quickened & preserved by the spirit of
Christ, and needeth not any polver be
getative.
Although therefore these very bo
dies & memders which now we heare
shall after the resurrection be in Hea
ven, yet neverthelesse because they
are clarified and cleansed from all cor
ruption, and feeling of the natural bo
die, there shall not be verily any na
tural or corruptible sense or affection,
nor use of the carnall body and mem
bers. And this doth the Lorde affirme
agaynst the Sadduces that breamed
of marriages in Heaven, or rather by
that absurditie, made a mocke of the

polver and the quickening spirite. For the Apostle himselfe shewing what he meant by ye naturall & spirituall body, addeth this immediatly & saith: There is a naturalll bodye, and there is a spiri tuall bodie : as it is written. The first man Adam was made a living soule, and the last Adam was made a dure kening spirite. And yet agayne more plainely he sayth: Howbeit that is not first which is spirituall, but that which is naturall, and then that which is spy rituall. The first man is of the earth earthly:the second man is the Lord from heaven. As is the earthly, suth are they that are earthly: fas is the heavenly, suth are they also that are heavenlie, And as we have born the image of the earthly, so shal wee beare the image of the heavenlie. So then Paul calleth that naturall bodie and earthly body, which wee have of our first father A dam, whose quickening is of the soule and by it doeth live. And hee calleth the spiritual body, and heavenly body, which wee have of Christ, and made to the likenesse of the body of Christ, which although it bee a very body in deede, and the fleshe thereof bee very flesh indeed, yet notwithstanding it is quickened & preserved by the spirit of Christ, and needeth not any polver be getative. Although therefore these very bo dies & memders which now we heare shall after the resurrection be in Hea ven, yet neverthelesse because they are clarified and cleansed from all cor ruption, and feeling of the natural bo die, there shall not be verily any na tural or corruptible sense or affection, nor use of the carnall body and mem bers. And this doth the Lorde affirme agaynst the Sadduces that breamed of marriages in Heaven, or rather by that absurditie, made a mocke of the
resurrection, where hee sayeth: The
sonnes, of this worlde marrie wives,
and give in marriage: but they that
shal be thought worthie of that world
and of the resurreetion from the dead
doe neither marrie wives, nor give in
marriage: neither can they die anie
more. For they are equall to the An
gels, and are the sonnes of God, assoone
as they be the sonnes of resurrection.
To which effect also Paul saythr Vlesh.
and bloud can not inherite the king
dome of GOD. And least peradven
ture any man shoulde mistake hys
words, and thinke that he spake of the
substance of the flesh, he addeth imme
diatly this for interpretation therof, &
saith, Neither shall corruption inherit
incorruption.
Wherefore flesh & bloud, that is to
saye, the affections and lustes of the
fleshe, shall not bee in the Clect that
live in heaven. For the ioyes of Hea
ven doe differ a great deale from the
ioyes of the earth, & are so farre foorth
of another condition, that they cannot
admit such corrupt creatures to be in
heritours of them, & for that cause the
corruptible bodies must first be purged
from all corruption, & by that meanes,
purely clarified. The Turkes therfore
are deceyved that looke for earthly
ioyes,
Moreover the bodies of the wicked
shall also rise againe. For Paul in the
Actes saith: I beleeve all that is writ
ten in the Lawe and the Prophetes
hoping in God that the resurrection
of the dead, which they themselves
looke for also, shalbe both of the just,
and uniust. See heere, the Apostle saith
of the uniust also. But in this resur
rection there shall not be taken out of
their bodies, the infirmitie, corrupti
on, dishonour and miserie : for even
then that very body rising againe and

resurrection, where hee sayeth: The sonnes, of this worlde marrie wives, and give in marriage: but they that shal be thought worthie of that world and of the resurreetion from the dead doe neither marrie wives, nor give in marriage: neither can they die anie more. For they are equall to the An gels, and are the sonnes of God, assoone as they be the sonnes of resurrection. To which effect also Paul saythr Vlesh. and bloud can not inherite the king dome of GOD. And least peradven ture any man shoulde mistake hys words, and thinke that he spake of the substance of the flesh, he addeth imme diatly this for interpretation therof, & saith, Neither shall corruption inherit incorruption. Wherefore flesh & bloud, that is to saye, the affections and lustes of the fleshe, shall not bee in the Clect that live in heaven. For the ioyes of Hea ven doe differ a great deale from the ioyes of the earth, & are so farre foorth of another condition, that they cannot admit such corrupt creatures to be in heritours of them, & for that cause the corruptible bodies must first be purged from all corruption, & by that meanes, purely clarified. The Turkes therfore are deceyved that looke for earthly ioyes, Moreover the bodies of the wicked shall also rise againe. For Paul in the Actes saith: I beleeve all that is writ ten in the Lawe and the Prophetes hoping in God that the resurrection of the dead, which they themselves looke for also, shalbe both of the just, and uniust. See heere, the Apostle saith of the uniust also. But in this resur rection there shall not be taken out of their bodies, the infirmitie, corrupti on, dishonour and miserie : for even then that very body rising againe and
